awd_titl_txt: Exploration of Chlamydomonas reinhardtii Epigenetic Regulation in a Research-Classroom Setting
awd_abstract_narration:
Basic research on the green microalgae Chlamydomonas reinhardtii (Chlamydomonas) has the potential to benefit society in many transformational ways, from the generation of sustainable biofuels to the synthesis of novel compounds. This project aims to expedite realization of these benefits by investigating a fundamental mechanism governing algal gene expression–the packaging of DNA by histone proteins and their chemical modification. The research will decipher components of the algal "histone code" that influence how algae control gene expression. The project will be undertaken at Saint Mary’s College of California, a primarily undergraduate, Hispanic-Serving Institution (HSI) and features intensive research collaborations at national and regional laboratories in Berkeley, CA and St. Louis, MO. It will provide research training opportunities in the laboratory for several students during summer and the academic year, and will be integrated into the classroom to create unique, course-based undergraduate research experiences (CUREs) for ~80 students over a four-year period. Moreover, community college students, also from an HSI, will have the opportunity to shadow molecular biology students working on the CUREs, giving them insights into upper-division science at a 4-year university. 

Little research has been done on how histone modifications influence Chlamydomonas' epigenetic regulation and chromatin structure. The project will address this question through research and educational objectives that: (1) determine the function and epigenetic role of a newly discovered monomethylation on histone H4 by identifying and characterizing the enzyme responsible; (2) investigate histone methyltransferase gene expression by harnessing the power of student numbers in a course-based undergraduate experience (CURE); and (3) ascertain the role histone H4 monomethylation plays in higher-order chromatin structure and stability by immunofluorescent staining and microscopy. The outcomes will provide key spatiotemporal and mechanistic insights into histone modifications and the modifying enzymes in Chlamydomonas. This information will be of interest to researchers studying evolution of histone-based epigenetic regulation across plants, animals and fungi, and advance the use of algae as a source of biofuel and bioproducts.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
The key project outcomes generated upon the completion of NSF MCB award number 1943439 centered on the development of cutting-edge approaches to study gene expression-altering proteins in algae, a source for potential biofuel and bioproducts, and hands-on training of a diverse population of undergraduate and graduate students at Saint Mary's College of California, a primarily undergraduate institutions (PUI) and Hispanic-Serving Institution (HSI). Notable intellectual merit and broader impact products generated by this award are the following: a total of four peer-reviewed publications in highly respected proteomic/biochemistry journals, six accepted peer-reviewed professional conference abstracts, sixteen mentored undergraduate independent study projects, and ~160 undergraduate/master’s students experienced course-based authentic research experiences over the project's five-year period.

The project's overarching research aim centered around characterizing histone proteins, which are partly responsible for controlling microalgal (e.g., Chlamydomonas reinhardtii) gene expression. This understanding would unlock genetic engineering optimization for microalgae to potentially increase its utility in sustainable energy production through lipid production or enhanced absorption of the global-warming gas carbon dioxide. To accomplish this, proteins must first be extracted from the algae, specifically from its nucleus. Our paper published in the journal Methods (Wong et al., 2019) established a quick and robust procedure to isolate high-quality histone proteins from cell-walled Chlamydomonas and other photosynthetic organisms. This method was then used to conduct a deeper proteomic investigation of Chlamydomonas' histones through a collaboration with the Donald Danforth Plant Science Center (St. Louis, MO) and the Pacific Northwest National Laboratory (Richland, WA). The resulting work was published in the Journal of the American Society for Mass Spectrometry (Rommelfanger et al., 2021) and dramatically increased the number of histone proteoforms identified and quantified compared to previous studies. Importantly, several of these histone proteoforms were found to exhibit modifications and abundances unique to Chlamydomonas (or at least in the algal/plant lineage). Many of these unique histone proteoforms were found on proteins histone H3 and H4, which play critical roles in yeast and mammalian gene expression. We found that the isomeric complexity arising from protein modifications on histone H3 and H4 made manual identification and quantitation excessively time-consuming, so we developed and published an R software package called IsoForma to streamline data analysis and reduce processing time (Degnan et al., 2024). We also developed and published additional computational tools for the mass spectrometry community through the open-source Python application called pyMS-Vis, which provides an easy-to-use interface for quantifying and visualizing proteoforms (Pesavento et al., 2024). In summary, the project outcomes for this award have made significant contributions to the field of algal epigenetics by providing the tools necessary to now investigate the function of these histone proteoforms and the enzymes responsible for their functionally significant chemical modification.  We expect no less than three additional manuscripts to be generated from this award once the outstanding data have been analyzed.

The project contributed to broader societal impacts by providing hands-on student mentoring and training through authentic research experiences, both by sixteen one-on-one independent studies and several classroom-wide research projects. Of the twelve female and four male students who were individually mentored, four presented their work at national conferences and four were co-authors on peer reviewed publications. All sixteen mentored students went on to careers in STEM (biotechnology industry, medical school or graduate school), with several of them winning prestigious awards (e.g., NSF Graduate Research Fellowship, UT Austin Provost Graduate Excellence Fellowship, etc.). Furthermore, approximately 160 students (undergraduates and masters) participated in course-based research experiences in the courses that I teach: molecular biology, biochemistry, advanced molecular biology, and advanced research methods in biotechnology. They developed cutting-edge scientific skills and contributed to the main research aims through learning and applying such techniques as enzyme purification and assay development, CRISPR gene editing, real-time quantitative PCR, and mass spectrometry-based proteomics. Their cumulative results shaped the direction and speed of my research program by generating preliminary data that I could follow-up during the more productive summer months. Many of the students taking these courses do not have the ability to conduct mentored research, so this opportunity helps develop their critical thinking skills and confidence gained by an authentic research experience. Furthermore, many of these students are women (60%) and/or come from unrepresented groups in STEM (42%), so their training will contribute to a more diverse, globally competitive STEM workforce.

The outcomes of this project have received both local and national attention. At the local level, the projects of the grant have been highlighted at Saint Mary's College (see Saint Mary's Magazine - Spring 2020 issue [https://tinyurl.com/2k6j53zx]; 'Scientists at Work' series- January 2025 [https://tinyurl.com/3tbe7amr]). At the national level, the Donald Danforth Plant Science Center issued a press release on our Analytical Chemistry manuscript [https://tinyurl.com/2j479bvu], which was then picked up by news outlets www.phys.org, www.the-microbiologist.com, and www.azolifesciences.com.
